title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ORLANDO – On a night where offensive fireworks were expected, it was a singular, historic defensive masterpiece that stole the show. In a grinding 93-88 victory for the Orlando Magic over the Washington Bullets, the story was not written on the scoreboard but in the stat sheet next to Dikembe Mutombo’s name: 31 rebounds.

The legendary center delivered a performance for the ages, a dominant rebounding clinic that single-handedly strangled the Bullets’ hopes. In an era defined by high-flying scorers, Mutombo’s work on the glass was a brutal reminder of basketball’s fundamental truth: possession is everything.

While Orlando’s Anfernee Hardaway provided the offensive spark with a team-high 25 points, every possession was underpinned by Mutombo’s colossal presence. Each missed shot, whether from Washington’s Chris Webber (22 points) or Gheorghe Muresan (10 points), seemed destined for Mutombo’s waiting hands. He controlled the paint with an iron will, snatching defensive boards to extinguish Bullets’ chances and creating second and third opportunities for his own team on the offensive end.

Washington fought valiantly, with Webber and Calbert Cheaney (19 points) keeping the score tight. But every time they inched closer, Mutombo was there—a towering obstacle, swatting away hopes with his rebounds as effectively as his famed finger-wagging blocks.

In the end, the final score was secondary. This was Mutombo’s game, a relentless, 48-minute exhibition of defensive dominance. On this night in 1997, the most thunderous statement was not a dunk or a three-pointer, but the simple, repeated sound of the ball meeting Mutombo’s hands, securing another piece of history for the Orlando Magic.
